Posts.Content: Mar 19, 2016 05:02PM phrogger78 wrote: Oh and I side note, the nurse who did my pre op also is stage iv and has mets in the same spots as me. It was so fantastic to meet her and see that she is still working as a nurse. It gave me so much hope.
Posts.Title: Had my oophorectomy yesterday. phrogger78 RonnieKay

Posts.Content: Mar 19, 2016 05:01PM phrogger78 wrote: Thanks all, its still going quite well and I am not having any referred shoulder pain (thanks for mentioning that, I did know about it, but so many people don't, it is a good reminder). getting up and moving a little bit, not over doing it, but walking around a little bit really helps to prevent the gas from causing the shoulder pain. I only had one zoladex injection and had planned on just doing that until the summer but I am so glad I didn't. My OB and school instructors really pushed me to do it sooner (I am in nursing school so they all just wanted my ovaries out like yesterday). So I am glad I went ahead with it. The only down part is I can't drive a long distance because of the risk of DVT and this weekend my kids have a HUGE band competition and I couldn't go. I am however watching it on tv, they are streaming it live so I get to watch it. Then on top of it, my grandma died the day before my surgery and her funeral is today and that is almost 4 hours away so I didn't go to that either (it is ok, I was not close to my grandma but I did want to see my aunts, uncles and cousins). So ladies, no reason to put it off if you can get them out, it really is ok. I haven't taken a motrin since Friday morning and I haven't taken any pain pills at all. I will save those for later as a just in case for something else, but motrin was enough for a day for me.
Posts.Title: Had my oophorectomy yesterday. phrogger78 RonnieKay

Posts.Content: Mar 21, 2016 01:25AM phrogger78 wrote: I just started my second round of Ibrance and I am taking letrozole as well. I had my oophorectomy on Thursday so I am hoping all of this will give the meds a chance at doing a fantastic job. I still have no symptoms to speak of. No shortness of breath, no major side effects of the meds. I have some sore muscles and joints rarely, and the pain is so minor that I often forget to even mention it. I have no pain to speak of from my surgery. The worst side effect are hot flashes (they sucks) and headaches. I got headaches every cycle a day or two before my period started so at the lowest point of my estrogen levels. Now that I was on zoladex then had my oophorectomy, I don't expect it to be much better, but I will live with it. I am a little weird, I have my own pulse oximeter and I make sure my O2 levels are within ranges. I never thought I would be concerned with it, but now knowing I have a tumor in my lung, i just make sure I am taking in enough oxygen.
Posts.Title: mets to lung bhd1 movingsoccermom

Posts.Content: Mar 21, 2016 12:26PM phrogger78 wrote: Suersis, I have had the pulse ox for a while, my youngest has asthma but I use it now too. I have so many BP cuffs it is actually kind of funny (I have 4 different sizes), I used them in my EMT course and now in nursing school, there are too many different sized arms in our class, so I have made my oldest son check my BP often. He is an EMT as well and is hopefully starting nursing school. Now if only I could have a 12 lead at home, we could have too much fun playing with tools. I am glad I am not the only one who has one though.
Posts.Title: mets to lung bhd1 movingsoccermom

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2016 01:04AM phrogger78 wrote: My cancer is very hormone receptive Mylen, so removing my ovaries, it reduces the amount of estrogen and progesterone in my body, which helps fuel the cancer. I can't eliminate all the hormones in my body (there are other glands in the body that make the hormones, but not at the same levels that the ovaries do), but I can reduce them and hopefully that will give the anti hormone medication a better chance at working and stopping progression. So if your cancer isn't hormone receptive, that might be a reason why the Dr wouldn't want to remove them. I started off with a medication that causes chemical menopause, but I quickly had surgery (within 4 weeks of my first injection), the oncologist and the gynecologist really wanted to get them out sooner than later.

Posts.Title: Had my oophorectomy yesterday. phrogger78 RonnieKay

Posts.Content: phrogger78 wrote: I had my surgery and I am actually amazed at how well I am doing after the surgery. I thought for sure I would have more pain than what I am having. I am glad that the ob convinced me to do it sooner, I had planned on waiting until the summer to do it, instead we decided to do it right before spring break, so I have a week off from school then I should be nice and rested by the time we go back to school. So I just wanted to let anyone know, if you are thinking about a laparoscopic oophorectomy, it really isn't too bad at all. Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2016 05:01AM phrogger78 wrote: Yeah I am one who doesn't really feel pain. Laparoscopic surgery is less invasive in that they aren't cutting the muscle, that is true. However once the probes are in the abdomen, the surgeons are rough, to the point I was kind of shocked watching the surgeries. I will still go for a lap procedure when ever possible, but I guess what I am saying is when people are still in a ton of pain after a lap procedure, I can't say I blame them at all.
Posts.Title: Meeting with the Gynecologist next Tuesday phrogger78 phrogger78

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2016 03:52AM phrogger78 wrote: I may be joining you ladies soon. I saw my Oncologist on Monday and the results of my PET scan were not great. I knew my cancer was in my lymph nodes, but it seems it has gone much further than just the nodes in the axilla, it might be in the nodes around the mediastinum, but they also found a nodule in my lungs. The nodule itself is larger than my dang tumor. I have to have another biopsy, this time of my lung, and I am hoping it is Valley Fever. The Dr. does believe it could be valley fever but the fear is there that it is not. I am 37 with 4 kids, my youngest being only 6. I am a full time nursing student and all I have ever wanted to do is help other people, not depend on others for help for myself. Its just frustrating and scary to not have the exact answers I want and need right now. So my question is, I know everyone is stage 4 has been through the emotional ups and downs of this disease, at the diagnosis, I was totally fine and comfortable knowing I would beat this, now I know I won't beat it if it is in my lungs, but I know I can live a while with treatment, so how did you do that and still be strong for your family and still find it was worth it to continue with the things in life that make you happy?

He is a breast specialist and I am fairly lucky that my nursing school instructor, she was the former breast cancer coordinating nurse for the largest breast cancer facility in all of central CA. (so figure from northern LA to San Francisco) and she hand picked this oncologist for me. So I do at least have great confidence in him, but it never hurts to get another opinion and one of the first things he said to me was I will send you anywhere you want to get a second opinion.

Posts.Title: Meeting with the Gynecologist next Tuesday phrogger78 phrogger78

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2016 09:29AM phrogger78 wrote: I am having chemo done first. My tumor looks fairly small and it is not HER2+ however the surgeon and the oncologist (they have consulted but I have not met the oncologist yet) have decided that chemo is going to be first. Everything I have read so far, it seems like a fantastic option for me. I would prefer to have surgery over the summer as I am a full time student and this won't interfere to much with school, but also my lymph nodes in my axilla were positive at my biopsy so the surgeon explained that it can help preserve some of my lymph nodes. No guarantee, but it could and that is good enough for me. I would rather not have to remove too many. I am having a PET scan tomorrow then next Monday I will meet with the oncologist and hopefully I will start chemo soon.
Posts.Title: Chemo first. Anyone else? Myraknits

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2016 01:28AM phrogger78 wrote: I have school aged kids as well. My youngest is 6, then I have a daughter who is 8 ( but she doesn't live with me, I had her for a gay couple but she knows I am her mother and she knows what is going on) then I also have a son who is 10 and a daughter who is almost 12 and again I had them for a gay couple and they know I am their mother but I don't know if they know what is going on, their fathers do, but I unfortunately don't get to see them as much I as do my younger daughter, then I have a step son who is 16, my son who is 16 and my oldest son is 19. So each kid has responded pretty well (the ones I know, know) my oldest boys understand what stage 4 means, they get that there is no guarantee I will be around for a long time, but they are hopeful that I will respond well to treatment and stick around for as long as possible. My step son doesn't quite understand it. He has autism and while he is doing very well, he just doesn't quiet get the gravity of it all. The youngest two just know I have cancer but they don't know that it will never be cured. My youngest boy thinks if I eat enough broccoli I won't have cancer. Thanks stupid commercials. We have not done counseling and really haven't done much of anything outside of treatments. I feel very good, I show no symptoms so I really just let them live their lives. We make tons of cancer jokes, but I think that is how we all cope, make light of things, even though we all know the gravity of it all.
